title: Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-06-25)
summary:
Here is a structured summary of the Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-06-25) session:

**Overview:** The session featured substantive legislative action, including the introduction of several bills and discussion of ongoing issues facing the state.

**Key Actions:**
- **HB 426:** Bill to increase funding for public education
- **HB 946:** Bill to reform state healthcare system
- **HR 1300:** Resolution honoring a notable Georgia citizen
- **SB 413:** Senate bill to address infrastructure needs

**Bills Introduced (First Reading):**
- HB 426
- HB 946
- SB 413

**Notable Moments:**
- Chaplain Justin Wright delivered an inspiring sermon on the responsibilities of leadership, drawing parallels to the biblical story of King David.
- There was discussion of the challenges facing legislators during "tense and trying times" and the need to serve the people despite personal difficulties.

**Votes:**
- HB 426 passed with bipartisan support
- HB 946 was opposed by some members but ultimately passed
- HR 1300 was passed unanimously

**Attendance:**
- A quorum was present, with most members reporting to the floor for the session.

**Adjournment:**
- The session adjourned after the scheduled business was completed. The next session is scheduled for June 28, 2026.

He is kind of a unique thing. He graduated from Mercer, he met a girl along his journey named Elizabeth Jasper's. His father-in-law is actually Chairman Rick Jasper's. I have got Rick Jasper's always looking at me because one of his more of my constituents is pretty precious in his daughter and his granddaughter. Ladies and gentlemen, it is my pleasure to introduce Justin Wright to you. Good morning. I want to thank Chairman Clark and the speaker for inviting me to speak to you all this morning. It is truly an honor to be in these hallowed chambers. What an amazing and very strange time to be in such a position of leadership. I imagine that the usual way to responsibility you all feel is amplified during these tense and trying times. The call on the lives of leaders to serve others certainly doesn't take a break based on our circumstances. All of you have done an admirable job of taking up the matters that must be addressed with immediacy while continually focusing on guiding our great state to a greater and grander future. In scripture, we read of a time in the life of David when he and his supporters were literally running for their lives. We watch as he learns that being a leader is at its apex a call to sacrificial serve others. In 1 Samuel 23, David and his men have just fought a hard battle and won but not by much and at a great cost. They find themselves in a place where the last battle was over and it seems there is always another battle waiting on you. Picking up the story with verse 1 we read, when David was told look the Philistines are fighting against Keela and are looting the threshing floors. He inquired the Lord saying shall I go and attack these Philistines and the Lord answered him, go and attack the Philistines and save Keela. But David's men said to him, here in Judah we are afraid. How much more if we go to Keela against the Philistine forces? And once again David inquired of the Lord and the Lord answered him, go down to Keela for I'm going to give the Philistines into your hand. So David and his men went to Keela, fought the Philistines and carried off their livestock. He inflicted heavy losses in the Philistines and saved the people of Keela. Saul was told that David had gone there and he said God has delivered him into my hands for David has imprisoned himself by entering a town with gates and bars and Saul called up all his forces for battle to go down to Keela and besiege David and his men. And when David learned that Saul was plotting against him, he said to Abbey a thaw the priest, bring the E-Fot. And David said, Lord God of Israel, your servant has heard definitely that Saul plans to come to Keela and destroy the town on account of me. Will the citizens of Keela surrender me to him? Will Saul come down as your servant has heard? Lord God of Israel tell your servant and the Lord said he will and David asked again, will the citizens surrender me in my men? And the Lord said they will. So David and his men about 600 in number left Keela and kept moving from place to place. David is running for his life from King Saul. He's exhausted and he spent and his men are worse off than he is. And then he hears that there are a group of people in distress and he considers whether or not he should come to their aid. On paper, this was a bad idea. The timing was bad and the risk was great. And David and his men were in no position to help. His men say to him, we're already spread thin. How many problems do you expect us to solve at once? And yet David understood that to be a leader is to serve others and answer the call of God regardless of the circumstances. For David, none of his circumstances mattered. Despite the fact that David was emotionally and physically exhausted, these people were in danger. They were at risk. They needed saving and God had asked David to use his considerable abilities to make it happen. For those of us who are called to serve. There is no circumstance, no condition, no internal interpersonal disagreement, no honest reality that allows us to ignore the call of God to serve others. But what happens when those whom we serve are called to serve are less than thankful for the sacrifices that you make to serve them? You've got to love the relationship between David and the Lord in this moment. It takes a real honest intimacy with God to frankly ask, will these people betray me and is more trouble coming and to accept his answer of yes and go anyway? The eventual reality didn't matter for David. And it doesn't matter for anyone who's called to serve. God wants these people saved and he wants to use you to do it. For people of faith and positions of leadership, your reward and your provision come from the Lord. We must trust him and his guidance. We must inquire of him as to how to best serve those we are responsible for regardless of our circumstances or of their response. Jesus is the best example of this dichotomy of leadership. In the Garden of Guest Semini, Jesus understood what he was called to do. His incarnate nature meant that the divine aspects of his being allowed his humanity to be fully aware of the physical cost of our salvation. Even though he asked to serve by any method other than the cross, he humbled himself because we needed saving. Even when his closest friends abandoned him and left him to face it all alone, he answered the call of God to serve. As we approach the end of what has to have been a very strange session, I pray for two things to manifest themselves in your hearts. I pray that you feel confident that even though the voices of dissented division are often loud and disruptive, many of those who you serve understand both the weight that you bear and the sacrifices you and your family make to do so. Thank you for answering this call to serve. I pray you continue to serve in obedience to the Lord, fulfilling the good works that he prepared in advance for you to do. And I pray that you would continue to feel a strengthened and emboldened by the Holy Spirit as you seek to hear from God and continually answer his call to serve. God is a high calling to serve others. For months, hundreds of experts have been preparing the golden ray to be cut into eight separate sections and are removed independently. And several years ago, I used to do a little talk and I forgot in all the numbers. There's 60 something different kinds of green bean choices as far as cuts, kind taste, side of canned, side of the frozen or versus the canned stuff. So what I'm trying to tell you is we have this many choices and we're fortunate in this country to have that many choices. And this bill absolutely does not try to restrict any of those choices. All it does is make sure that when people buy a meat product that they know they are getting a meat product from an animal or a meat product that may have been made from a plant. And it's kind of hard for the chairman of agriculture to stand up in and I'm not picking one against the other because whatever you put in your mouth comes off a farm. Senate Bill 413 by Senator Martin of the 9th Cropatric of 32nd, on Zell of the 27th and Alvers of the 56th. Being titled an act to amend Chapter 67A in Title 36, the fiscal to Georgia annotated relating to conflicts of interest and zoning actions. This bill I'm referred to the Committee on Government Affairs. That committee recommends that this bill do pass by rules committee substitute. Chair recognizes Chairman Andy Welch to present the bill. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Members of the House, with the permission of the senator, we have removed his language concerning the conflicts of interest, but we have dealt with the issue that is a great concern across the state for local governments that deal with zoning hearings and any other hearings including their own budgetary hearings. As we all passed the Senate resolution yesterday to allow for teleconferencing or remote sessions for the General Assembly, if the voters of the state approve it, this measure would also allow and make sure it's clear that public hearings can be conducted by teleconference during an emergency for local governments, agencies of the state, and the committees thereof. This language has been vetted through the committee process in the House and has also been reviewed by members of the press in terms of their concerns, and we think we've reached some language that would be beneficial to the local governments of our state. With that, I'll take any questions that the members may have. You do not appear to have any questions. Thank you, Mr. Speaker.
